question: Question 2 In the circuit below, [latex]\mathrm{M}_{1}[/latex] is an ideal AC voltmeter and [latex]\mathrm{M}_{2}[/latex] is an ideal AC ammeter. The source voltage (in Volts) is [latex]\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}(\mathrm{t})=100 \cos (200 \mathrm{t})[/latex]. What should be the value of the variable capacitor C such that the RMS readings on [latex]\mathrm{M}_{1}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{M}_{2}[/latex] are 25 V and 5 A , respectively?
solution:
[latex]\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}(\mathrm{t})=100 \cos 200 \mathrm{t}[/latex] RMS readings of [latex]\mathrm{M}_{1}[/latex] voltmeter [latex]=25 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] RMS readings of [latex]\mathrm{M}_{2}[/latex] ammeter [latex]=5 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] Across RLC series circuit Impedance, [latex]Z=R+j\left(X_{L}-X_{C}\right)[/latex] [latex]|Z|=\sqrt{R^{2}+\left(X_{L}-X_{C}\right)^{2}}[/latex] [latex]\frac{M_{1}}{M_{2}}=\frac{|V|}{|I|}=\sqrt{R^{2}+\left(X_{L}-X_{C}\right)^{2}}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& 5=\frac{25}{5}=\sqrt{5^{2}+\left(\omega L-X_{C}\right)^{2}}=\sqrt{25+\left(200-X_{C}\right)^{2}} \\
& 25=25+\left(200-X_{C}\right)^{2} \\
& 200=X_{C} \Rightarrow 200=\frac{1}{\omega C} \\
& C=\frac{1}{200 \times 200}=\frac{10^{-4}}{4}=25 \times 10^{-6} \\
& C=25 \mu F
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

Question 18 Consider the circuit shown in the figure with input [latex]V(t)[/latex] in volts. The sinusoidal

solution:
[latex] i(t)=\frac{V(t)}{1+Z}[/latex] where, 
[latex]V(t)= \sin t [/latex] [latex] \because [/latex] Given i(t) is lagging (from plot) [latex] \begin{aligned}
 I_{max}&=\frac{V_{max}}{Z}=\frac{1}{Z}\\

as\; \omega &=1(\sin \omega t)=\sin t

question:
Question 19 For the circuit shown, the locus of the impedance [latex] Z(j\omega )[/latex] is plotted as [latex]\omega [/latex] increases
from zero to infinity. The values of [latex] R_1[/latex] and [latex] R_2[/latex] are:
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
Z(j\omega )&=R_1+\frac{R_2\cdot 1/j\omega c}{R_2+ 1/j\omega c}\\
&=R_1+\frac{R_2}{\frac{1}{2}+jR_2\omega c}\\
Z(j\omega )_{\omega =0}&=R_1+R_2\\
\Rightarrow R_1+R_2&=5k\Omega \\
Z|j\omega |_{\omega \rightarrow \infty }&=R_1\\
\Rightarrow R_1&=2k\Omega \\
 R_2&=3k\Omega 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 The current [latex]I[/latex] in the circuit shown is ________
solution:
Applying Nodal equation at Node-A [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{V_A}{2k}+\frac{V_A-5}{2k}&=10^{-3}\\
\Rightarrow 2V_A-5&=2k \times 10^{-3}\\
V_A&=3.5V\\
Again,&\\
I&=\frac{5-V_A}{2k}\\
&=\frac{5-3.5}{2k}\\

question: Question 22 The circuit in the figure contains a current source driving a load having an inductor and a resistor in series, with a shunt capacitor across the load. The ammeter is assumed to have zero resistance. The switch is closed at time t = 0. Initially, when the switch is open, the capacitor is discharged and the ammeter reads zero ampere. After the switch is closed, the ammeter reading keeps fluctuating for some time till it settles to a final steady value. The maximum ammeter reading that one will observe after the switch is closed (rounded off to two decimal places) is _______________ A.
solution: Apply Laplace transform, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{s} &=\frac{V(s)}{1 / C s}+\frac{V(s)}{R+L s} \\ \frac{1}{s} &=V(s)\left[C s+\frac{1}{R+L s}\right] \\ V(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)}{C s+\frac{1}{R+L s}} \\ V(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)(R+L S)}{L C s^{2}+R C s+1} \\ I(s) &=\frac{(1 / s)(R+L s)}{L C s^{2}+R C s+1} \cdot \frac{1}{(R+L s)} \\ I(s) &=\frac{1 / L C}{s\left(s^{2}+\frac{R}{L} s+\frac{1}{L C}\right)} \\ L &=10 \mathrm{mH} ; C=100 \mathrm{pF} ; R=5 \times 10^{3} \Omega\\ \xi &=\frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}}=\frac{5 \times 10^{3}}{2} \sqrt{\frac{100 \times 10^{-12}}{10 \times 10^{-3}}}=0.25 \\ \text{Max}. \text { over shoot } &=e^{-\pi \xi / \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=0.44 \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum value = Steady state + Max. overshoot [latex] =1+0.44[/latex] [latex] =1.44 \mathrm{~A}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 In the circuit shown in the figure, the switch is closed at time [latex]t=0[/latex]
, while the capacitor is initially charged to [latex]-5\:V (i.e., v_{c}(0)=-5V)[/latex]
. The time after which the voltage across the capacitor becomes zero (rounded off to three decimal places) is ________________ [latex]\text{ms}[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)&=-5 \mathrm{~V} \\ V_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)&=-5 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] t \rightarrow \infty,[/latex] capacitor acts as a O.C. Write KCL at node [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{c}(\infty)-5}{250}+\frac{V_{R}}{500}+\frac{V_{c}(\infty)}{250} &=0 \\ V_{c}(\infty) &=\frac{5}{3} \text { Volts } \\ \text { Time constant }(\tau) &=R_{e q} C \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{V}{250}+\frac{V_{R}}{500}+\frac{V}{250} \\ V_{R} &=-V \\ I &=\frac{V}{250}-\frac{V}{500}+\frac{V}{250} \\ \frac{V}{I} &=\frac{500}{3} \Omega ; R_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{500}{3} \Omega \\ \tau &=\frac{500}{3} \times 0.6 \mu=0.1 \times 10^{-3} \\ v_{c}(t) &=v_{c}(\infty)+\left(v_{c}(0)-v_{c}(\infty)\right) e^{-\sqrt{2}} \\ v_{c}(t) &=\frac{5}{3}+\left(-5-\frac{5}{3}\right) e^{-t / 0.1 \times 10^{-3}} \\ 0 &=\frac{5}{3}-\frac{20}{3} e^{-10000 t} \\ t &=0.1386 \mathrm{msec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Inductor and capacitors are connected to the inductance source for a long time, so these elements have reached steady state. [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{L}\left(0^{-}\right) &=\frac{20}{5 \mathrm{k} \Omega+5 \mathrm{k} \Omega+10 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=1 \mathrm{~mA} \\ \mathrm{~V}\left(0^{-}\right) &=10 \mathrm{~V} \\ t &=0^{+} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} i\left(0^{+}\right)+\frac{10}{5 k}+1 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~A} &=0 \\ i\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right) &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ C \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ 1 \times 10^{-3} \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~mA} \\ \frac{d V\left(\mathrm{O}^{+}\right)}{d t} &=-3 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 The RC circuit shown below has a variable resistance R(t) given  by the following expression: [latex]R(t)=R_0\left ( 1-\frac{t}{T} \right ) \; for \;0\leq t \lt T[/latex] where [latex]R_0=1\Omega[/latex], and C=1F. We are also given that [latex]T=3R_0C[/latex] and the source voltage is [latex]V_s=1V[/latex]. If the current at time t=0 is 1A, then the current I(t), in amperes, at time t=T/2 is ___________(rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} T=3 R_{0} C=3 \mathrm{sec} \\ R(t)=\left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) ; 0 \leq t \leq 3 \mathrm{sec} \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} R(t) i(t)+\frac{1}{C} \int i(t) d t&=1 \\ \left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) i(t)+\int i(t) d t&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Differentiating both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) \frac{d i}{d t}-\frac{i}{3}+i &=0 \\ (3-t) \frac{d i}{d t}+2 i &=0 \\ \frac{d i}{i} &=-\frac{2}{(3-t)} d t \end{aligned}[/latex] Integrating on both sides, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} \ln (i)&=2 \ln (3-t)+\ln (c)\\ i(t)&=c(3-t)^{2} ; t \geq 0\\ \text{Given that,} i(0)&=1 A.\\ \text{So,}\quad c(3-0)^{2} &=1 \mathrm{A} \\ c &=\frac{1}{9} \mathrm{A} \\ i(t) &=\frac{1}{9}(3-t)^{2} \mathrm{A}\\ \text{At }t&=\frac{T}{2}=1.5 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(1.5)&=\frac{1}{9}(1.5)^{2}=0.25 A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 In the circuit shown, if [latex]v(t)=2sin(1000t)[/latex] volts, [latex]R=1k\Omega[/latex] and [latex]R=C=1\mu F[/latex], then the steady-state current [latex]i(t)[/latex], in milliamperes (mA), is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Here,}X_{C}&=\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{10^{3} \times 10^{-6}}=\frac{1}{10^{-3}}\\ x_{C} &=10^{3} \Omega \\ R &=10^{3} \Omega \quad \text { (Given) } \\ v(t) &=2 \sin 1000 t \vee=2 \angle 0^{\circ} \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] Redrawing the given network, we get, As the bridge is balanced, it can be redrawn as [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad Y_{e q} &=Y_{1}+Y_{2} \\ &=\frac{3}{2} R+\frac{1}{-2 j X_{C}} \\ &=\frac{3}{2} \times 10^{-3}+j \frac{1}{2} \times 10^{-3} \\ \therefore \quad i(t) &=(t) \times Y_{\mathrm{eq}}=2 \angle 0^{\circ}\left[\frac{3}{2}+j \frac{1}{2}\right] \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ &=(3+j 1) \mathrm{mA} \\ &=3 \sin (1000 t)+\cos (1000 t) \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 Consider the two-port resistive network shown in the figure. When an excitation of 5 V is applied across Port 1, and Port 2 is shorted, the current through the short circuit at Port 2 is measured to be 1 A (see (a) in the figure). Now, if an excitation of 5 V is applied across Port 2, and Port 1 is shorted (see(b) in the figure), what is the current through the short circuit at Port 1?
solution: According to reciprocity theorem, In a linear bilateral single source network the ratio of response to excitation remains the same even after their positions get interchanged. [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{I}{5}=\frac{1}{5} \Rightarrow I=1 \mathrm{A}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Consider the network shown below with [latex] R_{1} = 1\Omega , R_{2} = 2\Omega  \; and \; R_{3} = 3\Omega  [/latex]. The network is connected to a constant voltage source of 11V. The magnitude of the current (in amperes, accurate to two decimal places) through the source is _______.
solution: As the network is symmetric, [latex]V_{A}= V_{B} and V_{C}= V_{D}[/latex] So current throught [latex]R_{2}[/latex] resistor is zero and [latex]V_{A}=V_{B}[/latex] and [latex]V_{C}[/latex]=[latex]V_{D}[/latex],electrically the circuit can reduced as, Total resistance, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{T} &=2\left(R_{1} \| R_{1}\right)+\left(R_{1}\left\|R_{1}\right\| R_{3} \| R_{3}\right) \\ &=R_{1}+\left(\frac{R_{1}}{2} \| \frac{R_{3}}{2}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that, [latex]R_{1}=1 \Omega[/latex] and [latex]R_{3}=3 \Omega [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{So,}\qquad R_{T} &=1+\left(\frac{1}{2} \| \frac{3}{2}\right) \Omega=1+\frac{3 / 2}{4}=\frac{11}{8} \Omega \\ I &=\frac{11 \mathrm{V}}{R_{T}}=\frac{11}{(11 / 8)}=8 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 For the circuit given in the figure, the magnitude of the loop current (in amperes, correct to
three decimal places) 0.5 second after closing the switch is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Loop current, } i(t)&=\frac{1}{1+1}\left(1-e^{-t / \tau}\right) \mathrm{A} ; t \gt 0 \\ \tau&=\frac{L}{R_{e q}}=\frac{1}{1+1}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t)&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-e^{-2 t}\right) \mathrm{A} ; t \gt 0\\ \text{At }t=0.5 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(t)&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-e^{-1}\right) \mathrm{A}=0.316 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 For the circuit given in the figure, the voltage [latex]V_{C}[/latex] (in volts) across the capacitor is
solution: [latex]\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{-6}}=200 \mathrm{k} \Omega[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{C} &=\frac{5 \angle 0^{\circ}}{200-j 200} \times(-j 200) \vee \\ &=\frac{5 \angle 0^{\circ} \times 1 \angle-90^{\circ}}{\sqrt{2} \angle-45^{\circ}} \mathrm{V} \\ &=\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}} \angle-45^{\circ} \mathrm{V}=2.5 \sqrt{2} \sin \left(5 t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \mathrm{V} \\ &=2.5 \sqrt{2} \sin (5 t-0.25 \pi) \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The ABCD matrix for a two-port network is defined by: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} V_{1}\\ I_{1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} A & B\\ C & D \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} V_{2}\\ - l_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The parameter B for the given two-port network (in ohms, correct to two decimal places)
is _______.
solution: [latex]B=-\left.\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}\right|_{V_{2}=0}[/latex] When [latex]V_{2}=0[/latex] (i.e., when port-2 is short circuited) [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{1}&=\frac{V_{1}}{2 \Omega+(5 \Omega \| 2 \Omega)}=\frac{7 V_{1}}{24 \Omega}\\ I_{2}&=-I_{1} \times \frac{5 \Omega}{5 \Omega+2 \Omega}=\frac{-5 V_{1}}{24 \Omega}\\ \text { So, } \quad B&=-\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{24}{5} \Omega=4.80 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The switch in the circuit, shown in the figure, was open for a long time and is closed at t = 0. The current i(t) (in ampere) at t = 0.5 seconds is ________
solution: The equivalent circuit at [latex]t = 0^{-}[/latex] is as follows: The Laplace transform model of the circuit for [latex]t \gt O[/latex]  is as follows: [latex] I(s)=\frac{10}{s}-\frac{12.5}{5+2.5 s}=\frac{10}{s}-\frac{5}{s+2}[/latex] By taking inverse Laplace transform, [latex] i(t)=\left(10-5 e^{-2 t}\right) u(t) \mathrm{A}[/latex] At t=0.5 seconds, [latex] i(t)=\left(10-\frac{5}{e}\right) A=8.16 \mathrm{A}[/latex]

question: Question 41 Consider the circuit shown in the figure. The Thevenin equivalent resistance (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) across P - Q is _________.
solution: The equivalent circuit to calculate the Thevenin equivalent resistance ([latex]R_{Th}[/latex]) is as follows: lt can be further reduced as follows: By applying KVL in the Loop L [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{x} &=3 i_{0}+\left(1-i_{0}\right)=2 i_{0}+1 \\ \text { Also, } \quad V_{x} &=i_{0}(1 \Omega) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { So, } 2 i_{0}+1&=i_{0} \\ i_{0} &=-1 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{x} &=-1 \mathrm{V}\\ \text { So, } \quad R_{\mathrm{Th}}&=\frac{V_{x}}{1 \mathrm{A}}=-1 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 A connection is made consisting of resistance A in series with a parallel combination of
resistances B and C. Three resistors of value 10[latex]\Omega[/latex], 5[latex]\Omega[/latex], 2[latex]\Omega[/latex] are provided. Consider all possible permutations of the given resistors into the positions A, B, C, and identify the configurations with maximum possible overall resistance, and also the ones with minimum possible overall resistance. The ratio of maximum to minimum values of the resistances (up to second decimal place) is ____________.
solution: The connection of resistors is as shown below: Given resistor values are :[latex] 10 \Omega, 5 \Omega, 2 \Omega [/latex] The maximum resistance possible is, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{T(\max )} &=10 \Omega+(5 \Omega \| 2 \Omega) \\ &=\left(10+\frac{10}{7}\right) \Omega=\frac{80}{7} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] The minimum resistance possible is, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{T(\min )} &=2 \Omega+(10 \Omega \| 5 \Omega) \\ &=\left(2+\frac{10}{3}\right) \Omega=\frac{16}{3} \Omega \\ \frac{R_{T(\max )}}{R_{T(\min )}} &=\frac{80 / 7}{16 / 3}=\frac{15}{7}=2.143 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 In the circuit shown, V is a sinusoidal voltage source. The current I is in phase with voltage V. The ratio [latex]\frac{amplitude \; of \;  voltage \;  across \; the \; capacitor} {amplitude \; of \; voltage  \; across \; the \;  resistor}[/latex] is
solution: Given that, V and J have same phase. So, the circuit is in resonance. At resonance, [latex] \begin{aligned} &V_{C}=Q V_{R}\\ &\text { So, } \frac{\text { Amplitude of } V_{C}}{\text { Amplitude of } V_{R}}=Q=\frac{1}{R} \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}=\frac{1}{5} \sqrt{\frac{5}{5}}=0.2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 In the circuit shown, the voltage [latex]V_{IN}(t)[/latex] is described  by: [latex]V_{IN}=\left\{\begin{matrix} 0, & for \; t \lt 0\\ 15 \; volts & for \;  t\geq 0 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] where t is in seconds. The time (in seconds) at which the current I in the circuit will reach the value 2 Amperes is ___________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{s}t)&=\frac{V}{R}\left[1-e^{\frac{-R t}{L}}\right] \\ i_{s}t)&=\frac{15}{1}\left[1-e^{\frac{-3 t}{2}}\right]\\ \text{Current through }\ 2 \mathrm{H} \\ i(t)&=i_{s}t) \frac{1}{1+2}\\ i(t)&=5\left[1-e^{\frac{-3 t}{2}}\right] \mathrm{A}\\ \text{At }\;i(t)=2 \mathrm{A} \\ 2&=5\left[1-e^{\frac{-3 t}{2}}\right]\\ \text{By solving,} t&=0.3405 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 The figure shows an RLC circuit exited by the sinusoidal voltage [latex]100 \cos (3t)[/latex] volts, where t is in seconds. The ratio [latex]\frac{amplitude \; of \;  V_{2}}{amplitude \; of  \; V_{1}} [/latex] is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega &=3 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} ; Z_{1}=(4+j 3) \Omega \\ \text{and}\quad Z_{2} &=(5-j 12) \Omega \\ \left|V_{2}\right| &=|i|\left|z_{2}\right|=|i| \sqrt{5^{2}+12^{2}}=13|i| \\ \left|V_{1}\right| &=|i|\left|z_{1}\right|=|i| \sqrt{4^{2}+3^{2}}=5|i| \\ \frac{\left|V_{2}\right|}{\left|V_{1}\right|} &=\frac{13|i|}{||5 1}=\frac{13}{5}=2.6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 In the circuit shown, the positive angular frequency [latex]\omega [/latex] (in radians per second) at which magnitude of the phase difference between the voltages [latex]V_1 \; and \; V_2[/latex] equals [latex]\pi/4[/latex]  radians, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let,}i(t)&=I_{m} \angle \theta_{i} and Z_{2}=1+j \omega \\ &=\sqrt{1+\omega^{2}} \angle \theta_{2} \\ \theta_{2} &=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega}{1}\right) \\ V_{1} &=i(t)(1 \Omega)=I_{m} \angle \theta_{i} \\ V_{2} &=i(t) Z_{2}=I_{m} \sqrt{1+\omega^{2}} \angle \theta_{2}+\theta_{i} \end{aligned}[/latex] From the given data, [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\theta_{i}+\theta_{2}\right)-\left(\theta_{i}\right)&=\frac{\pi}{4}\\ \theta_{2}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega}{1}\right)&=\frac{\pi}{4}\\ \omega&=1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 The z-parameter matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} z_{11} &z_{12} \\ z_{21}& z_{22} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] for the two-port network shown is
solution: Redrawing the circuit, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{11} &=\frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}=3 \| 6=2 \Omega \\ V_{2} &=-3 \times I_{3 \Omega}=-3 \times I_{1} \times \frac{6}{9}=-2 I_{1} \\ \therefore Z_{21} &=\frac{V_{2}}{I_{1}}=-2 \\ \text { Now, } Z_{22} &=\left.\quad \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0}=3 \| 6=2 \Omega \\ V_{1} &=-6 \times I_{6 \Omega} \\ &=-6 \times I_{2} \times \frac{3}{9} \\ &=-2 \\ \therefore[Z] &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -2 \\ -2 & 2 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 the RLC circuit shown in the figure, the input voltage is given by [latex]v_{i}(t)=2cos(200t)+4sin(500t)[/latex] The output voltage [latex]v_{0}(t)[/latex] is
solution: Where, [latex]V_{i}(t)=2 \cos (200 t)+4 \sin (500 t)[/latex] As different frequencies are operating, using superposition theorem, we get for [latex]\omega=200 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} x_{L}=\omega L=(200)(0.25)=50 \Omega \\ x_{C}=\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{200 \times 100 \times 10^{-6}}=50 \Omega \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0}(t) &=V_{i}(t) \\ X_{L} &=0.4 \times 500=200 \Omega \\ X_{C} &=\frac{1}{10 \times 10^{-6} \times 500}=200 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad V_{0}(t)&=V_{i}(t) \\ \text { Therefore } \quad V_{0}(t)&=2 \cos (200 t)+4 \sin (500 t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The switch S in the circuit shown has been closed for a long time. It is opened at time t=0 and remains open after that. Assume that the diode has zero reverse current and zero forward voltage drop. The steady state magnitude of the capacitor voltage [latex]V_{c}[/latex] (in volts) is ______
solution: At [latex]t = 0^{-}[/latex] [latex] i_{L}\left(0^{-}\right)=\frac{10}{1}=10 \mathrm{A}[/latex] For [latex]t>0[/latex] (using Laplace transform) [latex] \begin{array}{l} I(s)=\frac{10 \times 10^{-3}}{10^{-3} s+\frac{10^{6}}{10 s}} \\ V_{c}(s)=I(s) \times \frac{10^{6}}{10 s} \\ V_{c}(s)=\frac{10^{6}}{s^{2}+10^{8}} \end{array}[/latex] Taking inverse Laplace, we get [latex] V_{c}(t)=100 \sin 10^{4} t \mathrm{V}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Steady state magnitude voltage across capacitor is 100V.

question: Question 52 In the circuit shown in the figure, the magnitude of the current (in amperes) through [latex]R_{2}[/latex] is ___
solution: Using KVL in the outer loop [latex] 60-5\left(0.16 V_{x}\right)-\frac{V_{x}}{5} \times 3-V_{x}=0[/latex] [latex] \text{or}\quad v_{x}=25 \mathrm{V} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] The current flowing through [latex] R_{2}=\frac{V_{x}}{5}=\frac{25}{5}=5 \mathrm{A}[/latex]

question: Question 53 In the given circuit, each resistor has a value equal to 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. What is the equivalent resistance across the terminals a and b?
solution: [latex]R_{eq}\Rightarrow[/latex] By using delta to star conversion Again by star to delta conversion [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{\mathrm{ab}} &=\{4 \| 1)+(4 \| 1)\}\|\{1 \| 4)\} \\ &=\left(\frac{4}{5}+\frac{4}{5}\right) \| \frac{4}{5}=\frac{8}{15} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 The z-parameter matrix for the two-port network shown is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2j\omega & j\omega \\ j\omega & 3+2j\omega \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where the entries are in [latex]\Omega[/latex]. Suppose [latex]Z_{b}(j\omega )=R_{b}+j\omega[/latex]. Then the value of [latex]R_{b}[/latex]  (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) equals ________
solution: For T-network, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{11} &=Z_{a}+Z_{c} \\ Z_{22} &=Z_{b}+Z_{c} \\ \text { and, } \quad Z_{12} &=Z_{21}=Z_{c} \\ \text { Given, } &[Z]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 j \omega & j \omega \\ j \omega & 3+2 j \omega \end{array}\right] \\ \text { Therefore } Z_{12} &=j \omega \\ \text { and, } \quad Z_{22} &=3+2 j \omega \\ &=3+j \omega+j \omega \\ &=Z_{b}+Z_{c} \\ &=R_{b}+j \omega+Z_{c} \\ & R_{b}=3 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 The figure shows an RLC circuit with a sinusoidal current source. At resonance, the ratio |[latex]I_{L}[/latex]|/|[latex]I_{R}[/latex]|, i.e., the ratio of the magnitudes of the inductor current phasor and the resistor current phasor, is ________
solution: At resonance (for parallel RLC circuit) [latex] \begin{array}{l} I_{R}=I \\ I_{L}=Q I \angle-90^{\circ} \\ I_{C}=Q I \angle 90^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex] For parallel RLC circuit [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\left|I_{L}\right|}{\left|I_{R}\right|} &=\frac{I Q}{I}=Q=R \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} \\ &=10 \sqrt{\frac{10 \times 10^{-6}}{10 \times 10^{-3}}}=0.316 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 The switch has been in position 1 for a long time and abruptly changes to position 2 at t=0. If time t is in seconds, the capacitor voltage [latex]V_{C}[/latex]  (in volts) for [latex]t \gt 0[/latex] is given by
solution: at[latex] t = 0^{-}[/latex], Switch is at position-1 where, [latex]\quad V_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)=\frac{10 \times 2}{2+3}=4 \mathrm{V} \ldots(1) \\ \therefore \quad V_{c}(0-)=V_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)=4 \mathrm{V} [/latex] [latex] \text{at }t = \infty[/latex] [latex] V_{c}(\infty)=5 \times 2=10 \mathrm{V}[/latex] The time constant of the circuit is [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=R_{\mathrm{eq}} C_{\mathrm{eq}} \\ &=(4+2) \times 0.1=0.6 \mathrm{sec} \\ \therefore V_{c}(t)=V_{c}(\infty) &+\left[V_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)-V_{c}(\infty)\right] e^{-t / \tau} \\ &=10+(4-10) e^{-t / 0.6} \\ V_{c}(t) &=\left(10-6 e^{-t / 0.6}\right) \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 In the circuit shown below, [latex]V_{S}[/latex] is a constant voltage source and [latex]I_{L}[/latex] is a constant current load. The value of [latex]I_{L}[/latex] that maximizes the power absorbed by the constant current load is
solution: In maximum power transformation, half of the voltage drops across source resistance, remaining half across the load. [latex]\therefore[/latex] voltage across source (R) [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{L} R &=\frac{V_{s}}{2} \\ I_{L} &=\frac{V_{s}}{2 R} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 58 In the circuit shown in the figure,
the maximum power (in watt) delivered to the resistor R is __________
solution: For maximum power transfer, [latex] \begin{array}{l} R=R_{T h} \\ V_{0}=5 \times \frac{2 \mathrm{k} \Omega}{5 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=2 \mathrm{V} \end{array}[/latex] From output loop, [latex]V_{T H}=100 \times 2 \times \frac{40 \mathrm{k} \Omega}{50 \mathrm{k} \Omega}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} V_{\mathrm{TH}}=160 \mathrm{V}\\ \text { and } R_{\mathrm{TH}}=10 \mathrm{k} \Omega|| 40 \mathrm{k} \Omega=\frac{10 \times 40}{50}=8 \mathrm{k} \Omega \\ \therefore \text { Maximum power }=\frac{V^{2}_{\mathrm{Th}}}{4 R_{\mathrm{Th}}}=\frac{160 \times 160}{4 \times 8000}=0.8 \mathrm{W} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 59 An AC voltage source V = 10 sin(t) volts is applied to the following network. Assume that [latex]R_{1}=3k \Omega [/latex], [latex]R_{2}=6k \Omega [/latex] and [latex]R_{3}=9k \Omega [/latex], and that the diode is ideal. RMS 
 current [latex]I_{rms}[/latex] (in mA) through the diode is ________
solution: The equivalent resistance across terminal ah ( outer loop) is [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{I}{3} \times 3 \mathrm{k} \Omega+\frac{I}{6} \times 6 \mathrm{k} \Omega+\frac{I}{3} \times 9 \mathrm{k} \Omega \\ V &=5 I \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{V}{I} &=5 \mathrm{k} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] For half wave rectifier [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{\mathrm{rms}} &=\frac{I_{m}}{(2)}=\frac{10 \sin t}{5 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=2 \sin t \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ \therefore \quad I_{\mathrm{rms}} &=\frac{I_{m}}{2}=1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 In the circuit shown, the current I flowing through the 50 [latex]\Omega [/latex] resistor will be zero if the value of capacitor C (in [latex]\mu[/latex]F) is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\mathrm{eq}} &=\frac{j 5 \Omega \times\left(\frac{1}{j \omega C}+j 5\right)}{j 5 \Omega+j 5 \Omega+\frac{1}{j \omega C}} \\ I &=0 \text { if } Z \text { is } \infty \\ Z &=Z_{\mathrm{eq}}+50+j 5\\ \text{For z to be } \infty, Z_{e q}&=\infty \\ \Rightarrow j 5+j 5+\frac{1}{j \omega C}&=0\\ 10 &=\frac{1}{5000 \times C} \\ C &=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{3} \times 10}=20 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 At very high frequencies, the peak output voltage [latex]V_{0}[/latex] (in Volts) is ________.
solution: Circuit contains balanced Wheat-stone bridge. Also at high frequencies capacitor can be considered as short circuits. Redrawing the circuit [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0} &=1 \sin \omega t \times 1 k \Omega=0.5 \sin \omega t \\ \text { Peak output } &=0.5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 In the circuit shown, the voltage [latex]V_{X}[/latex] (in Volts) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{x}}{20}+\frac{V_{x}-V_{y}}{10}+0.5 V_{x}&=5 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{x}\left[\frac{1}{20}+\frac{1}{10}+0.5\right]&=5+\frac{V_{y}}{10} \\ 13 \mathrm{V}_{x}&=100+2 \mathrm{V}_{y} \quad\ldots(i)\\ \text { and also, } V_{y}&=0.25 \mathrm{V}_{x} \quad\dots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equations (i) and (ii), we have [latex] \begin{aligned} 52 V_{y} &=100+2 V_{y} \\ 50 V_{y} &=100 \Rightarrow V_{y}=2 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{x} &=4 V_{y}=8 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 For the circuit shown in the figure, the Thevenin equivalent voltage (in Volts) across terminals a-b is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{Th}&=V_{6\;\omega}\\ \frac{V_{A}-12}{3}+\frac{V_{A}}{6} &=V_{6 \Omega} \\ V_{A}\left[\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}\right] &=1+4 \\ V_{A} \frac{3}{6} &=5 \\ V_{T h} &=V_{6 \Omega}=V_{A}=10 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 In the circuit shown, the initial voltages across the capacitors [latex]C_{1}[/latex] and [latex]C_{2}[/latex] are 1V and 3V ,respectively. The switch is closed at time t = 0. The total energy dissipated (in Joules) in the resistor R until steady state is reached, is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Initial energy } &=\frac{1}{2}\left(C_{1} V_{1}^{2}+C_{2} V_{2}^{2}\right) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left(3 \times 1^{2}+1 \times 3^{2}\right)=6 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex] Final energy stored in capacitor [latex] \begin{aligned} &= \frac{1}{2}\left(C_{1}+C_{2}\right) V^{2} \\ C_{1} V_{1}+C_{2} V_{2}&=\left(C_{1}+C_{2}\right) V \\ 1 \times 3+3 \times 1&=(1+3) V \\ V&= 1.5 \mathrm{V} \\ \text { Final energy }&=\frac{1}{2}(1+3) \times(1.5)^{2}=4.5 \mathrm{J} \\ \text { Energy dissipated }&=6-4.5=1.5 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 In the circuit shown, the Norton equivalent resistance (in  [latex] \Omega[/latex]) across terminals a-b is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\frac{V_{0}}{4} \\ I_{1}&=\frac{V_{0}}{2}\\ \text{Applying KCL}\\ \frac{V_{0}-4 I}{2}+\frac{V_{0}}{2}+\frac{V_{0}}{4}&=I_{0}\\ \text{From here}\\ V_{0} \cdot \frac{3}{4} &=I_{0} \\ R_{N} &=\frac{V_{0}}{I_{0}}=\frac{4}{3}=1.33 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 An LC tank circuit consists of an ideal capacitor C connected in parallel with a coil of inductance L having an internal resistance R. The resonant frequency of the tank circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{e q}=& \frac{\frac{1}{j \omega C} \times(j \omega L+R)}{\frac{1}{j \omega C}+j \omega L+R} \\ Z_{e q}=& \frac{\left(\frac{R}{j \omega C}+\frac{L}{C}\right)}{R+j\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right)} \times \frac{R-j\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right)}{R-j\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Equating imaginary part to zero. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Img}&=-\frac{R^{2}}{\omega C}-\frac{L}{C}\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right)=0 \\ &\frac{R^{2}}{\omega C}+\frac{L}{C}\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right)=0 \\ &\frac{C R^{2}+\omega^{2} L^{2} C-L}{\omega C^{2}}=0 \\ \omega^{2}&=\frac{L-R^{2} C}{L^{2} C} \\ \omega&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L C} \sqrt{1-\frac{R^{2} C}{L}}} \\ f&=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}} \sqrt{1-\frac{R^{2} C}{L}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (80)^{2}+\left(40-V_{c}\right)^{2} &=100^{2} \\ \left(40-V_{C}\right)^{2} &=100^{2}-80^{2}=3600 \\ \left|40-V_{C}\right| &=60 \\ V_{C} &=100 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 In the given circuit, the maximum power (in Watts) that can be transferred to the load [latex]R_{L}[/latex] is_______.
solution: For maximum power transfer [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{L} &=\left|Z_{T h}\right|=|2 \| j 2| \\ &=\left|\frac{2 \times j 2}{2+j 2}\right|=1.414 \Omega \\ V_{T h} &=\frac{8 \angle 90^{\circ}}{2+j 2}=2.828 \angle 45^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{2.828 \angle 45^{\circ}}{1.414 \angle 45^{\circ}+1.414}=1.08 \angle 22.5^{\circ} \\ \text { Power } &=I^{2} R=(1.08)^{2} \times \sqrt{2}=1.649 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 In the circuit shown, switch SW is closed at t = 0. Assuming zero initial conditions, the value of [latex]v_{c}(t)[/latex] (in Volts) at t = 1 sec is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} & v_{c}\left(0^{-}\right)=0 \mathrm{V} \\ & v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)=0 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{c}(\infty)&=\frac{2}{2+3} \times 10 \\ &=4 \mathrm{V}[\text { By voltage divider }] \\ v_{c}(t)&=4\left[1-e^{-t / \tau}\right] \\ \tau &=R_{\mathrm{eq}} C=\frac{3 \times 2}{3+2} \times \frac{5}{6} \\ &=1 \mathrm{sec} \\ v_{c}(1) &=4\left[1-e^{-1 / 1}\right]=2.528 \mathrm{Volts} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The damping ratio of a series RLC circuit can be expressed as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\xi=\frac{1}{2 Q} ; Q=\frac{1}{R} \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}\\ &\therefore \text { Damping ratio }=\xi=\frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 In the circuit shown, the switch SW is thrown from position A to position B at time t = 0. The energy (in [latex]\mu[/latex]J) taken from the 3 V source to charge the 0.1 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor from 0 V to 3 V is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{c}\left(0^{-}\right) &=0 \mathrm{V} \\ v_{c}\left(0^{+}\right) &=0 \mathrm{V} \\ v_{c}(\infty) &=3 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{Time constant,}\\ \tau &=\mathrm{RC}=120 \times 0.1 \times 10^{-6} \\ \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{c}}(t) &=3+(0-3) e^{-t / \tau} \\ &=3\left(1-e^{-t / \tau}\right) \\ I_{\mathrm{c}}(t) &=\frac{\mathrm{Cd} v_{\mathrm{c}}(t)}{d t}=\frac{0.1 \times 10^{-6} \times 3 \times e^{-t / \tau}}{\tau} \\ &=\frac{0.1 \times 10^{-6} \times 3 e^{-t / \tau}}{120 \times 0.1 \times 10^{-6}} \\ &=\frac{1}{40} e^{-t / \tau} \\ \text { Energy } &=\int_{0}^{\infty} V_{I} d t \\ &=\left.\int_{0}^{\infty} 3 \cdot \frac{1}{40} \times e^{-t / \tau} \\ & =-\frac{3}{40} \times \tau e^{-t / \tau} \right|_{0}^{\infty}\\ &=\frac{3}{40} \times 12 \times 10^{-6}=0.9 \mu \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 In the given circuit, the values of [latex]V_{1} \; and \; V_{2}[/latex] respectively are

question: Question 78 In the circuit shown, at resonance, the amplitude of the sinusoidal voltage (in Volts) across the capacitor is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { At resonance, } I=\frac{10}{4} \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} \omega&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.1 \times 10^{-3} \times 10^{-6}}}=10^{5} \text { rad/sec } \\ X_{C}&=\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{10^{5} \times 1 \times 10^{-6}}=10 \Omega \\ V_{C}&=I X_{C}=10 \times \frac{10}{4}=25 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 80 The equivalent resistance in the infinite ladder network shown in the figure is [latex]R_{e}[/latex]. The value of [latex]R_{e}[/latex]/R is ____.
solution: For an infinite ladder network, if all the resistance are comprises of same value R, then Or [latex] \therefore \quad R_{\mathrm{eq}}=R+\frac{R \cdot R_{\mathrm{eq}}}{R+R_{\mathrm{eq}}}\qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] After solving equation (i) we get [latex] R_{\mathrm{eq}}=\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right) R\qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] From the given question, the circuit can be redraw as [latex] \therefore \quad R_{e}=R+R_{\mathrm{eq}} \qquad\ldots(iii)[/latex] From equation (ii) and (iii) we get. [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{e} &=R+\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\right) R=2.618 R \qquad\ldots(iv)\\ \text { or } \frac{R_{e}}{R} &=2.618=2.62 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 In the circuit shown in the figure, the value of [latex]v_{0}(t)[/latex] (in volts) for [latex]t\rightarrow \infty[/latex] is____.
solution: At steady state the inductor act as a short circuit. [latex] \therefore \quad V_{x}=5 i_{x} [/latex] By KCL [latex] \begin{aligned} &-10+\frac{V_{x}-2 i_{x}}{5}+i_{x}=0\\ &-10+\frac{5 i_{x}-2 i_{x}}{5}+i_{x}=0\\ \text{or}&\\ \frac{8 i_{x}}{5} &=10 \\ \Rightarrow \quad i_{x} &=\frac{50}{8} \mathrm{A} \\ \therefore v_{0}(t) &=5 i_{x}(t)=\frac{5 \times 50}{8}=31.25 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 82 The steady state output of the circuit shown in the figure is given by
[latex]y(t)=A(\omega )sin(\omega t+\phi (\omega ))[/latex]. If the amplitude [latex]|A(\omega )|[/latex]= 0.25, then the frequency [latex]\omega[/latex] is
solution: Applying KCL at node A, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{V_{A}-\sin \omega t}{R}+\frac{V_{A}}{\frac{1}{j \omega C}}+\frac{V_{A}}{\frac{2}{j \omega C}}=0 &\ldots(i)\\ &=V_{A}\left[\frac{1}{R}+j \omega C+\frac{j \omega C}{2}\right]=\frac{\sin \omega t=1 \angle 0^{\circ}}{R} \\ &=V_{A}=\frac{2}{2+3 R C \cdot j \omega} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{Also }\quad Y&=\frac{V_{A}}{2}=\frac{1}{2+3 j \omega R C} &\ldots(iii)\\ \because|A(\omega)|&=\frac{1}{4} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{1}{4}&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4+9 \omega^{2}(R C)^{2}}} \\ or \quad \omega&=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3} R C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 86 In the circuit shown in the figure, the angular frequency [latex]\omega[/latex] (in rad/s), at which
the Norton equivalent impedance as seen from terminals [latex]b-b'[/latex] is purely resistive,
is _____.
solution: Finding [latex]Z_{N}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{b b}^{\prime} &=\frac{1 \times j 0.5 \omega}{1+j 0.5 \omega}+\frac{1}{j \omega}=\frac{j \omega}{2+j \omega}+\frac{1}{j \omega} \\ \text { or } Z_{b b}^{\prime} &=\frac{2-\omega^{2}+j \omega}{2 j \omega-\omega^{2}}&\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Rationalizing equation (i), we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{b b}^{\prime} &=\frac{\left(2-\omega^{2}\right)+j \omega}{2 j \omega-\omega^{2}} \times \frac{-\omega^{2}-j 2 \omega}{-\omega^{2}-j 2 \omega} \\ &=-\frac{2 \omega^{2}+\omega^{4}+2 \omega^{2}}{\omega^{4}+2 \omega^{2}}+j \frac{\left(\omega^{3}-4 \omega\right)}{\omega^{4}+2 \omega^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] In order to have a purely resistive impedance [latex]Z_{\text {bb }}^{\prime} [/latex], the imaginary part of equation (ii) will be equaled to zero. [latex] \begin{aligned} &\therefore \frac{-4 \omega+\omega^{3}}{\omega^{4}+2 \omega^{2}}=0\\ &\text{or}\quad \omega^{3}=4 \omega \\ &\text{or}\quad \omega=\sqrt{4}=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 In the circuit shown in the figure, the value of node voltage[latex]V_{2}[/latex] is
solution: Using the concept of super node, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1}-V_{2} &=10 \angle 0^{\circ} \qquad\ldots(i)\\ &=\frac{V_{1}}{-3 j}+\frac{V_{2}}{6 j}+\frac{V_{2}}{6}=4 \angle 0^{\circ} \qquad\ldots(ii)\\ &=\frac{-2 V_{1}+V_{2}+V V_{2}}{6 j}=4 \angle 0^{\circ}\qquad\ldots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (i) and (iii) [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{2} &=\frac{20+j 24}{(-1+j)}=\frac{31.241 \angle 50.194}{\sqrt{2} \angle 135^{\circ}} \\ &=22.091 \angle-84.806\\ \text{or }\quad V_{2}&=2-22 j \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 88 Consider the building block called 'Network N ' shown in the figure.
Let C = 100 [latex]\mu[/latex]F and R = 10 k[latex]\Omega[/latex]. Two such blocks are connected in cascade  as shown in the figure. The transfer function [latex]\frac{V_{3}(s)}{V_{1}(s)}[/latex] of the cascaded network is
solution: The cascaded network is, Applying mesh analysis to determine the current [latex] I_{2}(\mathrm{s}) [/latex] We get,, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left(R+\frac{1}{C s}\right) I_{1}(s)=R I_{2}(s)=V_{1}(s) \qquad \ldots(i)\\ \left(R+\frac{1}{C s}\right) I_{2}(s)-R I_{2}(s)=0 \qquad \ldots(ii) \end{array}[/latex] Also, [latex] V_{3}(s)=I_{2}(s) \times R \qquad \ldots(iii)[/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left(R+\frac{1}{C s}\right) \times\left(1+\frac{1}{R C s}\right) I_{2}(s)-R I_{2}(s)=V_{1}(s) \\ &=\left(\frac{R C s+1}{C S}\right)\left(\frac{R C s+1}{R C s}\right) I_{2}(s)-R I_{2}(s)=V_{1}(s) \\ \text{or } I_{2}(s) &=\frac{R C^{2} s^{2} V_{1}(s)}{(1+R C s)^{2}-R^{2} C^{2} s^{2}} \;\ldots(iv) \end{aligned}[/latex] Using equation (iii) and (iv), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{3}(s)}{V_{1}(s)}&=\frac{s^{2} R^{2} C^{2}}{1+3 R C s+s^{2} R^{2} C^{2}} \\ \because \qquad R&=10 \mathrm{k} \Omega, C=100 \mu \mathrm{F} \text{ and } R C=1 \\ \frac{V_{3}(s)}{V_{1}(s)}&=\frac{s^{2}}{1+3 s+s^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 In the figure shown, the value of the current I (in Amperes) is_____.
solution: Using super position theorem, when 5 V source acting alone, we get [latex] I_{1}=\frac{V}{R_{\mathrm{eq}}}=\frac{5}{10+5+5}=\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{A}\quad \ldots(i)[/latex] When 1 A source acting alone, we get [latex] I_{2}=\frac{1 \times 5}{5+10+5}=\frac{5}{20}=\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{A}\quad \ldots(ii)[/latex] Therefore, [latex] I=I_{1}+I_{2}=\frac{1}{2} A=0.5 \mathrm{A}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 A series RC circuit is connected to a DC voltage source at time t = 0. The
relation between the source voltage [latex]V_{S}[/latex], the resistance R, the capacitance C, and the current [latex]i(t)[/latex] is given below : [latex]V_{S}=Ri(t)+\frac{1}{C}\int_{0}^{t}i(u)du[/latex] Which one of the following represents the current [latex]i(t)[/latex] ?
solution: Given that: [latex] V_{s}=R i(t)+\frac{1}{C} \int_{0}^{t} i(t) d t\qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] Using Laplace transform, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { WS) }&=R I(s)+\frac{1}{C s} I(s) &\ldots(ii)\\ \text { or } I(s)&=\frac{V(s)}{\left(R+\frac{1}{C S}\right)} &\ldots(iii)\\ \text { For, } V(s)&=\frac{1}{s}&\ldots(iv) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (iii) and (iv), [latex] I(s)=\frac{C}{(R C s+1)}=\frac{1}{R\left(s+\frac{1}{R C}\right)}\qquad\ldots(v)[/latex] Using inverse Laplace transform in equation (v), we get, [latex] i(t)=\frac{1}{R} e^{-t / R C}[/latex] Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 92 In the figure shown, the capacitor is initially uncharged. Which one of the following
expressions describes the current I(t) (in mA) for t > 0 ?
solution: Converting the given circuit into frequency domain and applying KCL at V(s) We get, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{V(s)-\frac{5}{s}}{R_{1}}+\frac{V(s)}{R_{2}}+\frac{V(s)}{\frac{1}{C s}}=0 \quad\ldots(i)\\ \because \quad R_{1}=1 \mathrm{k} \Omega, R_{2}=2 \mathrm{k} \Omega \text { and } C=1 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{array}[/latex] Using the components value we get, [latex] V(s)\left[\frac{1}{1}+\frac{1}{2}+s\right]=\frac{5}{s}[/latex] or [latex]\quad V(s)=\frac{5}{s\left(s+\frac{3}{2}\right)} \quad\ldots(ii)[/latex] Using partial fraction on equation (ii) [latex] V(s)=\frac{10}{3 s}-\frac{10}{3\left(s+\frac{3}{2}\right)}\quad\ldots(iii)[/latex] Using inverse Laplace transform [latex] v(t)=\frac{10}{3}\left[1-e^{-\frac{3}{2} t}\right]\quad\ldots(iv)[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Current [latex]I=\frac{V(t)}{R_{2}}=\frac{5}{3}\left[1-e^{-\frac{3}{2} t}\right] m A[/latex]

question:
Question 93 In the h-parameter model of the 2-port network given in the figure shown, the
value of [latex]h_{22}[/latex] (in S ) in _____.
solution: When two, two port networks are connected in parallel then individual Y-parameters are added. Therefore from the given network, For network ( 1) Y-parameter is, [latex] Y_{1}=\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ -\frac{1}{3} & \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3} \end{array}\right][/latex] Similarly for network (2). [latex] \begin{aligned} Y_{2}=&\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 & -\frac{1}{2} \\ -\frac{1}{2} & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ \text { Thus, } \quad Y=Y_{1}+Y_{2}=&\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{5}{3} & -\frac{5}{6} \\ -\frac{5}{6} & \frac{5}{3} \end{array}\right] \\ \therefore \quad I_{1}=& Y_{11} V_{1}+Y_{12} V_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{5}{3} Y_{1}-\frac{5}{6} V_{2} &\ldots(i)\\ I_{2} &=Y_{21} V_{1}+Y_{22} V_{2} \\ &=-\frac{5}{6} V_{1}+\frac{5}{3} V_{2} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text { Also } \quad h_{22} &=\left.\frac{I_{2}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] From equation (i), we get, [latex] V_{1}=\frac{1}{2} V_{2} \qquad \ldots(iii)[/latex] and from equation (ii) and (iii), we get, [latex] h_{22}=\frac{I_{2}}{V_{2}}=\frac{15}{12}=1.25[/latex]

Question 97 In the circuit shown in the figure, the value of capacitor C (in mF) needed to
have critically damped response i(t) is _____.
solution: For critically damped system [latex] \xi=1=\frac{1}{2 Q}\quad \ldots(i)[/latex] where Q= Quality factor For series RLC circuit [latex] Q=\frac{1}{R} \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}\quad \ldots(ii)[/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{R} \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}&=1 \\ \text{or} \quad C&=\left(\frac{2}{R}\right)^{2} L=\left(\frac{2}{40}\right)^{2} \times 4=10 \mathrm{mF} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 A periodic variable x is shown in the figure as a function of time. The root-mean-square (rms) value of x is _____.
solution: [latex]\text { RMS value }=\sqrt{\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} x^{2}(t) d t}[/latex] where, T= time period for the given signal, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { RMS value }=\sqrt{\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T / 2}\left(\frac{2}{T} t\right)^{2} d t+\int_{T / 2}^{T}(0)^{2} d t}\\ =\sqrt{\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{1 / 2} \frac{4}{T^{2}} t^{2} d t}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{T} \times \frac{4}{T^{2}} \times\left(\frac{t^{3}}{3}\right)_{0}^{T / 2}} \\ =\sqrt{\frac{4}{T^{3}}\left(\frac{T^{3}}{24}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}}=0.408 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 A 230 V rms source supplies power to two loads connected in parallel. The first
load draws 10 kW at 0.8 leading power factor and the second one draws 10 kVA
at 0.8 lagging power factor. The complex power delivered by the source is
solution: Real power [latex](\mathrm{kW}) \mathrm{P}=\mathrm{VI} \cos \phi \qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad P_{1}=V \times I_{1} \cos \phi [/latex] Thus, [latex]l_{1}=\frac{10 \times 10^{3}}{230 \times 0.8}=54.34 \angle 36.86 \qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] Total power (kVA) [latex] P=V \cdot I_{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad I_{2}=43.47 \angle-36.86 \qquad \ldots(iii)[/latex] Therefore, [latex] \vec{I}=\vec{I}_{1}+\vec{I}_{2}=78.25+j 6.25 \qquad \ldots(iv)[/latex] So, the complex power delivered by source [latex] \begin{aligned} S&=V I^{*}=230(78.25-j 6.25) \\ \text{or}\quad S&=(18-j 1.5) \mathrm{kVA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 100 A Y-network has resistances of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex] each in two of its arms, while the third arm has a resistance of 11 [latex]\Omega[/latex] . In the equivalent [latex]\Delta[/latex]-network, the lowest value (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) among the three resistances is _____.
solution: According to the question The equivalent [latex]\triangle[/latex] -network of the above Y-network is [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Here, } R_{a} &=10+11+\frac{10 \times 11}{10}=32 \Omega \\ R_{b} &=10+11+\frac{10 \times 11}{10}=32 \Omega \\ R_{c} &=10+10+\frac{10 \times 10}{11}=29.09 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, the lowest value among the three resistances is [latex]29.09 \Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 101 Consider the configuration shown in the figure which is a portion of a larger
electrical network For R = 1[latex]\Omega[/latex]  and currents [latex]i_{1} = 2 A [/latex] ,[latex] i_{4} =- 1A[/latex] , [latex]i_{5}=- 4 A [/latex] , which one of the following is TRUE ?
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} i_{1}=2 \mathrm{A}, i_{4}=-1 \mathrm{A}, i_{5}=-4 \mathrm{A} \\ R=1 \Omega \end{array}[/latex] To calculate: [latex] i_{6}=?[/latex] Using KVL at all the three nodes we get, At node A [latex] i_{5}-i_{3}+i_{2}=0\qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] At node B [latex] i_{4}+i_{1}-i_{2}=0\qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] At node C [latex] i_{6}+i_{3}-i_{1}=0 \qquad \ldots(iii)[/latex] By putting the value of [latex]i_{3}[/latex] and [latex]i_{2}[/latex] from equation (i) and (ii) in equation (iii) we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{6}+\left(i_{2}+i_{5}\right)-i_{1}&=0 \\ i_{6}+\left(i_{1}+i_{4}+i_{5}\right)-i_{1}&=0 \\ \therefore \quad i_{6}+(2-1-4)-2&=0 \\ i_{6}&=5 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.C: Data is sufficient to conclude that the supposed currents are impossible
options.D: Data is insufficient to identify the currents [latex]i_{2},i_{3} \; and \; i_{6}[/latex]

Question 105 Three capacitors [latex]C_{1}[/latex], [latex]C_{2}[/latex] and [latex]C_{3}[/latex]  whose values are 10[latex]\mu[/latex]F, 5[latex]\mu[/latex]F, and 2[latex]\mu[/latex]F respectively, have breakdown voltages of 10V, 5V, and 2V respectively. For the interconnection shown below, the maximum safe voltage in Volts that can be applied across the combination, and the corresponding total charge in [latex]\mu[/latex]C stored in the effective capacitance across the terminals are respectively,
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=C V \\ Q_{1} &=C_{1} V_{1}=10 \times 10^{-6} \times 10=100 \mu \mathrm{C} \\ Q_{2} &=C_{2} V_{2}=5 \times 10^{-6} \times 5=25 \mu \mathrm{C} \\ Q_{3} &=C_{3} V_{3}=2 \times 10^{-6} \times 2=4 \mu \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] Capacitors [latex]C_{2}[/latex] and [latex]C_{3}[/latex] are in series. In series charge is same. So, the maximum charge on [latex]C_{2}[/latex] and [latex]C_{3}[/latex] will be minimum of [latex]\left(Q_{2}, Q_{3}\right)=\min (25 \mu C, 4 \mu C)=4 \mu C=Q_{23} [/latex] In series the equivalent capacitance of [latex]C_{2}[/latex] and [latex]C_{3}[/latex] is [latex] C_{23}=\frac{C_{2} C_{3}}{C_{2}+C_{3}}=\frac{5 \times 2}{5+2}=\frac{10}{7} \mu \mathrm{F}[/latex] So, the equivalent voltage [latex] V_{23}=\frac{Q_{23}}{C_{23}}=\frac{4 \times 10^{-6}}{\frac{10}{7} \times 10^{-6}}=\frac{28}{10}=2.8 \mathrm{V}[/latex] In parallel, the voltage is same. [latex] V_{1}=V_{23}=2.8 \mathrm{V}[/latex] Charge in capacitor [latex]C_{1} [/latex] [latex] Q_{1}=C_{1} V_{1}=10 \times 10^{-6} \times 2.8=28 \mu \mathrm{C}[/latex] In parallel, the total charge [latex] \begin{array}{l} Q=Q_{1}+Q_{23} \\ Q=4+28 \\ Q=32 \mu \mathrm{C} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 106 Two magnetically uncoupled inductive coils have Q factors [latex]q_{1}[/latex] and [latex]q_{2}[/latex] at the chosen operating frequency. Their respective resistances are [latex]R_{1}[/latex] and [latex]R_{2}[/latex] When connected in series, their effective Q factor at the same operating frequency is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} q_{1} &=\frac{\omega L_{1}}{R_{1}} \text { and } q_{2}=\frac{\omega L_{2}}{R_{2}} \\ \omega L_{1} &=q_{1} R_{1} \text { and } \omega L_{2}=q_{2} R_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Coils are connected in series. [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{0} q \cdot R &=\omega L_{1}+\omega L_{2}=q_{1} R_{1}+q_{2} R_{2} \\ q &=\frac{q_{1} R_{1}+q_{2} R_{2}}{R} \\ h &=R_{1}+R_{2} \\ q &=\frac{q_{1} R_{1}+q_{2} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 The following arrangement consists of an ideal transformer and an attenuator which attenuates by a factor of 0.8. An ac voltage [latex]V_{WX1}= 100V[/latex] is applied across WX to get an open circuit voltage [latex]V_{YZ1}[/latex] across YZ. Next, an ac voltage [latex]V_{YZ2}= 100V[/latex] is applied across YZ to get an open circuit voltage [latex]V_{WX2}[/latex] across WX. Then [latex]\frac{V_{YZ1}}{V_{WX1}}[/latex] , [latex]\frac{V_{WX2}}{V_{YZ2}}[/latex] are respectively,
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{Y Z_{1}} &=100 \times 1.25 \times 0.8 \\ &=100 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] In second case, when 100 V is applied at YZ terminals, this whole 100 V will appear across the secondary winding. Hence, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{w} x_{2}} &=\frac{100}{1.25}=80 \mathrm{V} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Y_{\mathrm{YZ}_{1}}}{Y_{\mathrm{wx}_{1}}} &=\frac{100}{100}, \frac{V_{\mathrm{w} \times 2}}{V_{\mathrm{YZ}_{2}}}=\frac{80}{100} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 In the circuit shown below, if the source voltage [latex]V_{s}= 100\angle 53.13^{\circ}V[/latex] then the Thevenin?s equivalent voltage in Volts as seen by the load resistance [latex]R_{L}[/latex] is
solution: To find [latex]V_{Th}[/latex], open circuit the load voltage [latex]R_{L}[/latex] then [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{2} &=0 \\ j 40 I_{2} &=0 \\ V_{L_{1}} &=\frac{V_{s} \cdot(j 4)}{3+j 4}=\frac{100 \angle 53.13^{\circ}}{5 \angle 53.13^{\circ}} \times 4 \angle 90^{\circ} \\ V_{L_{1}} &=80 \angle 90^{\circ} \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}} &=10 V_{L_{4}}+I_{2} j 6+I_{2} 3 \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}} &=10 \times 80 \angle 90^{\circ}+0 \times j 6+0 \times 3 \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}} &=800 \angle 90^{\circ} \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 A source [latex]v_{s}\left ( t \right )=V\cos 100\pi t[/latex] has an internal impedance of [latex]\left ( 4+j3 \right )\Omega[/latex]. If a purely resistive load connected to this source has to extract the maximum power out of the source, its value in [latex]\Omega[/latex] should be
solution:
For pure resistive load to extract the maximum power. [latex]
R_{L}=\left|Z_{s}\right|=\sqrt{R_{s}^{2}+X_{s}^{2}}=\sqrt{4^{2}+3^{2}}=5 \Omega[/latex]

Question 111 Consider a delta connection of resistors and its equivalent star connection as shown below. If all elements of the delta connection are scaled by a factor k, k>0, the elements of the corresponding star equivalent will be scaled by a factor of
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R_{A} &=\frac{R_{b} R_{c}}{R_{a}+R_{b}+R_{c}} \\ R_{a}^{\prime} &=k R_{a} \\ R_{b}^{\prime} &=k R_{b} \\ R_{c}^{\prime} &=k R_{c} \\ R_{A}^{\prime} &=\frac{k R_{b} \cdot k R_{c}}{k R_{a}+k R_{b}+k R_{c}}=\frac{k^{2} R_{b} R_{c}}{k\left(R_{A}+R_{b}+R_{c}\right)} \\ &=k \times \frac{R_{b} R_{c}}{R_{a}+R_{b}+R_{c}} \\ R_{A}^{\prime} &=k R_{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 112 With 10 V dc connected at port A in the linear nonreciprocal two-port network shown below, the following
were observed: (i) 1[latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 3 A (ii) 2.5  [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 2 A For the same network, with 6 V dc connected at port A, 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws 7/3 A. If 8 V dc is connected to port A, the open circuit voltage at port B is
solution: Case (i): [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{DC}}&=10 \mathrm{V}, R_{L}=1 \Omega, I=3 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}}&=I\left(R_{\mathrm{Th}}+R_{L}\right)=3\left(R_{\mathrm{Th}}+1\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{\mathrm{Th}}&=3 R_{\mathrm{Th}}+3 &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Case (ii): [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{L}&=2.5 \Omega, I=2 \mathrm{A}, V_{\mathrm{DC}}=10 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}}&=2\left(R_{\mathrm{Th}}+2.5\right) \\ V_{\mathrm{Th}}&=2 R_{\mathrm{Th}}+5 &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equations (i) and (ii) [latex] V_{\mathrm{Th}}=9 \mathrm{V} and R_{\mathrm{TH}}=2 \Omega \quad\ldots(iii)[/latex] Now, [latex]V_{Th}[/latex] depends on independent voltage source and varies with applied voltage. [latex]R_{Th}[/latex] does not depend on voltage source and is same for any applied voltage source, since voltage_ source is short circuited while calculating [latex]R_{Th}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{For }V_{\mathrm{DC}}&=6 \mathrm{V}, R_{\mathrm{L}}=1 \Omega, I=7 / 3 \\ V_{T h}&=I\left(R_{T h}+R_{L}\right) \\ V_{T h}&=\frac{7}{3}(2+1)=7 V &\ldots(iv) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \because [/latex]The network is linear and non reciprocal, it may contain dependent voltage source [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad V_{T h}&=a V+b \\ \Rightarrow \quad 9&=a 10+b \quad \text{from equation (iii)} \\ \text{and }\quad 7&=a 6+b \quad\text{from equation (iv)} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving, we get a=1/2 and b=4 [latex] \therefore \quad V_{\mathrm{Th}}=\frac{V}{2}+4=\frac{8}{2}+4=8 \mathrm{V}[/latex]

question:
Question 113 With 10 V dc connected at port A in the linear nonreciprocal two-port network shown below, the following
were observed: (i) 1[latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 3 A (ii) 2.5  [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B draws a current of 2 A With 10 V dc connected at port A, the current drawn by 7 [latex]\Omega[/latex] connected at port B is
solution: From the above solution [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { When, } & V_{\mathrm{DC}}=10 \mathrm{V} \\ \text { When, } & V_{\mathrm{Th}}=9 \mathrm{V} \text { and } R_{\mathrm{Th}}=2 \Omega \\ & R_{\mathrm{L}}=7 \Omega, I=? \\ & I=\frac{V_{\mathrm{Th}}}{R_{\mathrm{Th}}+R_{L}}=\frac{9}{2+7}=1 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 114 If [latex]V_{A}-V_{B}[/latex]=6V, then [latex]V_{C}-V_{D}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i &=\frac{V_{A}-V_{B}}{2}=\frac{6}{2} \\ &=3 \mathrm{A}\quad \ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] KCL at node B, we have [latex] \begin{aligned} i &=i_{2}+i_{1} \\ i_{2}+i_{1} &=3 \mathrm{A} \quad \ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] KCL at node E , we have [latex] i_{1}=i_{3}+i_{4}\quad \ldots(iii)[/latex] KCL at node D we have [latex] \begin{array}{l} i_{5}=i_{2}+i_{3}+i_{4} \\ i_{5}=i_{2}+i_{1} \\ i_{5}=3 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex] KCL at node F , we have [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{6}+2+i_{5}&=0\\ i_{6}&=-2-i_{5} \\ i_{6}&=-5 \mathrm{A}\\ \text{SO} \quad V_{C}-V_{D}&=1 \times i_{6}=-5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 115 Assuming both the voltage sources are in phase, the value of R for which maximum power is
transferred from circuit A to circuit B is
solution: Redrawing the diagram Current through R will be [latex] i=\frac{10-3}{2+R}=\left(\frac{7}{2+R}\right) \mathrm{A}[/latex] Current through 3V source is [latex] i_{1}=i-\frac{3}{-j 1}=i-3 j[/latex] So power delivered to circuit B by circuit A is [latex] \begin{array}{c} P=i^{2} R+i_{1} \times 3 \\ P=\left(\frac{7}{2+R}\right)^{2} \cdot R+\left(\frac{7}{2+R}-3 j\right) 3 \end{array}[/latex] for P to be maximum [latex]\frac{\partial P}{\partial R}[/latex] will be zero [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{\partial P}{\partial R}=0\\ \left(\frac{7}{2+R}\right)^{2}-\frac{98 R}{(2+R)^{3}}-\frac{21}{(2+R)^{2}}=0 \\ 49(2+R)-98 R-21(2+R)=0 \\ 98-42=49 R+21 R \\ R=\frac{56}{70}=0.8 \Omega \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 116 In the circuit shown below, the current through the inductor is
solution: According to KCL at node D there will be no current in voltage sources. According to KCL at node A current through inductor will be [latex] i_{1}=i+1\qquad \ldots(1)[/latex] Applying KVL in loop ACDBA we have [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 \times i+(i+1) j 1+1 \angle 0-1 \angle 0 &=0 \\ i+(i+1) j &=0 \\ (1+j) i &=-j \\ i &=\frac{-j}{1+j} &\ldots(2) \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore from (1) and (2) we have [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{1}&=i+1=\frac{-j}{j+1}+1\\ i_{1}&=\frac{1}{1+j} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 The impedance looking into nodes 1 and 2 in the given circuit is
solution: To find Thevenin impedance across node 1 and 2. Connect a 1 V source and find the current through voltage source. Then [latex]Z_{T h}=\frac{1}{I}[/latex] By applying KCL at node B and A [latex] \begin{aligned} i_{A B}+99 i_{b} &=I \\ i_{b} &=i_{A}+i_{A B}\\ \Rightarrow \quad i_{b}-i_{A}+99i_{b}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 100i_{b}-i_{A}&=I \ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying KVL in outer loop [latex] \begin{aligned} 10 \times 10^{3} i_{b}&=1\\ i_{b} &= 10^{-4}A\\ \text{and }10 \times 10^{3} i_{b}&=10^{1} \mathrm{A} \\ \Rightarrow \quad i_{A}&=-100 i_{b} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] From equation (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} 100 i_{n}+100 i_{n}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad I &=200 i_{b} \\ &=200 \times 10^{-4}=0.02 \\ \therefore \quad Z_{T h} &=\frac{1}{I}=\frac{1}{0.02}=50 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 120 In the circuit shown below, the initial charge on the capacitor is 2.5 mC, with
the voltage polarity as indicated. The switch is closed at time [latex]t[/latex] = 0. The current
[latex]i(t)[/latex] at a time [latex]t[/latex] after the switch is closed is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V(0) &=V\left(0^{+}\right)=\frac{Q}{C} \\ &=\frac{2.5 \times 10^{-3}}{50 \times 10^{-6}}=-50 \mathrm{V} \\ & \quad\because \text{(direction given is opposite)}\\ V(\infty)&=100 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V(t) &=V(\infty)+\left[V\left(0^{+}\right)-V(\infty)\right] e^{-\theta \tau} \\ &=100+(-50-100) e^{-j \tau} \\ V(t) &=100-150 e^{-t t} \\ i(t) &=C \frac{d V}{d t}=C \frac{150}{\tau} e^{-t / \tau} \\ \text { and } \tau &=10 \times 50 \times 10^{-6} \\ &=5 \times 10^{-4}\\ i(t) &=50 \times 10^{-6} \times \frac{150}{10 \times 50 \times 10^{-6}} e^{-2 \times 10^{3} t} \\ &=15 e^{-2 \times 10^{3} t} \mathrm{Amp} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 In the circuit shown below, the network N is described by the following Y matrix: [latex]Y=\begin{bmatrix} 0.1S & -0.01S\\ 0.1S& 0.1S \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. The voltage gain [latex]\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]I_{2}=Y_{21} V_{1}+Y_{22} V_{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad I_{2}=0.01 V_{1}+0.1 V_{2} \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] From given figure, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{2} &=-I_{2} R_{L}=-100 I_{2} \\ \therefore \quad I_{2} &=-\frac{V_{2}}{100} \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting value of [latex]I_{2}[/latex] in equation (i). [latex] \begin{aligned} -\frac{V_{2}}{100}&=0.01 V_{1}+0.1 V_{2}\\ \Rightarrow-0.01 V_{2}-0.1 V_{2}&=0.01 V_{1}\\ \Rightarrow-0.11 V_{2}&=0.01 V_{1} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}&=-\frac{0.01}{0.11} \\ or, \quad \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}&=-\frac{1}{11} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 In the circuit shown below, the current I is equal to
solution: Converting delta into star, the circuit can be redrawn as below: Equivalent impedance of the circuit, [latex] \begin{aligned} z&=(2+j 4) \|(2-j 4)+2 \\ z&=\frac{(2+j 4)(2-j 4)}{2+j 4+2-j 4}+2 \\ \Rightarrow \quad z&=\frac{4+16}{4}+2=7 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, Eurrent, [latex]I=\frac{14 \angle 0^{\circ}}{7}=2 \angle 0^{\circ} \mathrm{A}[/latex]

Question 124 In the circuit shown below, the Norton equivalent current in amperes with
respect to the terminals P and Q is
solution: For Norton equivalent current short circuiting the terminal PQ. Short circuit current [latex] \begin{aligned} l_{sc} &=\frac{25}{15+j 30+25} \times 16 \angle 0^{\circ} \\ &=\frac{25}{40+j 30} \times 16 \lt 0 =\frac{(25 \times 16) \angle 0^{\circ}}{50 \angle 3686}\\ &=8 \lt -36.86^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence Norton current is [latex] \begin{array}{l} l_{N}=I_{S C}=8 \angle-36.86^{\circ} \\ I_{N}=(6.4-j 4.8) \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 125 The circuit shown below is driven by a sinusoidal input [latex]v_{i} = v_{p} cos (t/RC)[/latex]. The steady state output [latex]v_{o}[/latex]
solution: Redrawing the circuits-domain [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{i}(s) &=\left(R+\frac{1}{s C}\right) I(s)+\frac{R \cdot \frac{1}{s C}}{R+\frac{1}{s C}} I(s) \\ V_{i}(s) &=\frac{1+s C R}{s C} I(s)+\frac{R}{1+s C R} I(s) \\ \because \quad v_{i} &=V_{p} \cos (t / R C) \qquad \ldots(i)\\ \text{so here,} \qquad \omega&=\frac{1}{R C} \\ Now,V_{i}(s)&=\frac{(1+j \omega C R)}{j \omega C} I(s)+\frac{R}{(1+j \omega C R)} I(s) \\ \text{Put,}\quad \omega&=\frac{1}{R C} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { So, } \quad V_{i}(s)&=\left[\frac{(1+j) R}{j}+\frac{R}{1+j}\right] I(s)\\ \frac{V_{i}(s)}{I(s)} &=\frac{3 R}{(1+j)} \qquad\ldots(ii)\\ I(s) &=\frac{V_{i}(s)}{3 R} \times(1+j) \\ \text { Now, } V_{0}(s) &=\left(R \| \frac{1}{s C}\right) I(s) \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{0}(s) &=\frac{R \cdot \frac{1}{s C}}{R+\frac{1}{s C}} I(s) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad V_{0}(s)&=\frac{R}{1+S C R} \cdot \frac{V_{i}(s)}{3 R}(1+j) \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{0}(s)&=\frac{R}{1+j} \cdot \frac{V_{i}(s)}{3 R}(1+j) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad V_{0}(s)&=\frac{V_{i}(s)}{3} \\ \text{In time domain,}\\ v_{0}(t)&=\frac{1}{3} v_{i}(t) \\ \Rightarrow \quad v_{0}(t)&=\frac{V_{p}}{3} \cos \left(\frac{t}{R C}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 In the circuit shown, the power supplied by the voltage source is
solution: Applying KVL in outer loop, [latex] \begin{aligned} (3+i) 2+(2+i) 2&=10 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad 6+2 i+4+2 i&=10 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad 4 i&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad i&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Power supplied by the voltage source, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=V_{i} \\ &=10 \times 0=0 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 The current I in the circuit shown is
solution: [latex](L=20 \mathrm{mH}, C=50 \mu \mathrm{H}) [/latex] Nodal analysis at node A, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{V_{A}-20}{j \omega L}+\frac{V_{A}}{1}+\frac{V_{A}}{1 / j \omega C}=0 \\ V_{A}\left[\frac{1}{j 10^{3} \times 20 \times 10^{-3}}+1+j 10^{3} \times 50 \times 10^{-6}\right] \\ =\frac{20}{j 10^{3} \times 20 \times 10^{-3}} \\ V_{A}\left[\frac{-j}{20}+1+\frac{j}{20}\right]=-j 1 \\ V_{A}=-j 1 V \\ I=\frac{V_{A}}{1}=-j 1 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 128 In the circuit shown, the switch S is open for a long time and is closed at [latex]t=0[/latex].  The current [latex]i(t)[/latex] for  [latex]t\geq 0^{+}[/latex] is
solution: Method 1: At [latex]t = 0^{-}[/latex]. the circuit is shown below: Current will divide equally in both [latex]10\Omega[/latex] resistors as shown in diagram. At [latex]t\geq 0^{+}[/latex], the circuit ins-domain is shown below: [latex] [L = 15 mH, i(O+) = i(O^{-}) = 0.75 A][/latex] The above circuit can be rearranged as given below: Applying nodal analysis, [latex]\begin{aligned} &\frac{V(s)-\frac{1.5}{s}}{10}+\frac{V(s)}{10}+\frac{V(s)+15 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.75}{10+15 \times 10^{-3} s}=0 \\ &\frac{\frac{V(s)}{10}+\frac{V(s)}{10}+\frac{V(s)}{10+15 \times 10^{-3} s}}{10 s}-\frac{15 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.75}{10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}} \\ &=\frac{15}{10}\left[\frac{10+15 \times 10^{-3} s+5}{5\left(10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}\right)}\right]\\ & \text { V(s) }\left[\frac{10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}+5}{5\left(10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}\right)}\right] \\ =& 15\left[\frac{10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}-10 \mathrm{s} \times 10^{-3} \times 0.75}{10\left(10+15 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}\right)}\right] \\ & \text { (1 }\left.+10^{-3} \mathrm{s}\right) V(s)=\frac{\left(10+7.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{s}\right)}{2 s}\left[\frac{s+1000}{1000}\right] \\ &V(s) =\frac{10000+7.5 \mathrm{s}}{2000 \mathrm{s}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} V(s)=\frac{10000+7.5 s}{2 s(s+1000)} \\ =\frac{10000}{2 \times 1000 s}+\frac{\{10000+7.5(-1000)\}}{2(-1000)(s+1000)} \\ =\frac{5}{s}-\frac{1.25}{s+1000} \end{array}[/latex] Taking inverse Laplace transform, [latex] \begin{aligned} v(t)&=5-1.25 e^{-1000 t} \mathrm{V}\\ i(t) &=\frac{v(t)}{10} \\ &=0.5-0.125 e^{-1000 t} \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex] Method 2: [latex] \begin{aligned} i\left(0^{+}\right)&=\frac{0.75}{2}=0.375 \mathrm{A}\\ i(\infty) &=0.5 \mathrm{A} \\ i(t) &=i(\infty)-\left\{i(\infty)-i\left(0^{+}\right)\right\} e^{-R t L} \end{aligned}[/latex] where, R = equivalent resistance seen across L with current source opened [latex] \begin{aligned} R &=10+(10 \| 10)=15 \Omega \\ i(t) &=0.5-\{0.5-0.375\} e^{-15 t 15 \times 10^{-3}} \\ &=0.5-0.125 e^{-1000 t} \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 For parallel RLC circuit, which one of the following statements is NOT correct?
solution:
Characteristic equation for a parallel RLC circuit is [latex]
s^{2}+\frac{1}{R C} s+\frac{1}{L C}=0[/latex] where, Bandwidth= [latex]\frac{1}{RC}[/latex] (i) It is clear that the bandwidth of a parallel RLC 
circuit is independent of L and decreases if 
R is increased. (ii) At resonance, imaginary part of input 
impedance is zero. Hence, at resonance input 
impedance is a real quantity. (iii) In parallel RLC circuit, the admittance is 
minimum at resonance. Hence magnitude of 
input impedance attains its maximum value 
at resonance.

options.A: The bandwidth of the circuit decreases if R is increased
options.B: The bandwidth of the circuit remains same if L is increased
options.C: At resonance, input impedance is a real quantity
options.D: At resonance, the magnitude of input impedance attains its minimum values

question: Question 130 For the two-port network shown below, the short-circuit admittance parameter matrix is
solution: Short-circuit admittance parameters for a two-port [latex]\pi[/latex]-network are, [latex] \begin{array}{l} Y_{11}=Y_{a}+Y_{b} \\ Y_{12}=Y_{21}=-Y_{b} \\ Y_{22}=Y_{b}+Y_{c} \end{array}[/latex] For the given network, [latex] \begin{aligned} Y_{a}&=Y_{b}=Y_{c}=\frac{1}{0.5}=2 \mho\\ \text{So,}Y_{11}&=2+2=4 \mho\\ Y_{12}&=Y_{21}=-2 \mho\\ Y_{22}&=2+2=4 \mho \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 132 In the circuit shown, what value of [latex]R_{L}[/latex] maximizes the power delivered to [latex]R_{L}[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { For } P_{\max } ; \quad R_{L}&=R_{\mathrm{eq}} \\ \mathrm{KVL} 1&=4 I_{1}+V_{x} &\ldots(1)\\ V_{x}&=4\left(I-I_{1}\right) &\ldots(2)\\ \text { Simplifying } R_{\mathrm{eq}}&=\frac{1}{I}=4 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 An AC source of RMS voltage 20 V with internal impedance [latex]Z_{s}=(1+2j)\Omega[/latex] feeds a load of impedance [latex]Z_{L}=(7+4j)\Omega[/latex] in the figure below. The reactive power consumed by the load is

question: Question 135 If the transfer function of the following network is [latex]\frac{V_o(s)}{V_i(s)}=\frac{1}{2+sCR}[/latex] The value of the load resistance [latex]R_{L}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z &=\frac{R_{L}}{1+S R_{L} C} \\ H(s) &=\frac{Z}{Z+R}=\frac{R_{L}}{\left(R_{L}+R\right)+S R R_{L} C} \\ \text{if}\quad R &=R_{L} \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{2+s R C} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 In the interconnection of ideal sources shown in the figure, it is known that the 60 V source is absorbing power. Which of the following can be the value of the current source I ?
solution: Since, the power is absorbed by 60 V source [latex] \begin{aligned} I^{\prime} &=12-I \\ \Rightarrow \quad I^{\prime} & \gt 0 \\ 12-I & \gt 0 \\ I & \lt 12 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 A fully charged mobile phone with a 12 V battery is good for a 10 minute talktime. Assume that, during the talk-time the battery delivers a constant current of 2 A and its voltage drops linearly from 12 V to 10 V as shown in the figure. How much energy does the battery deliver during this talk-time?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=V I \\ \text { Energy } &=P \cdot t=V \cdot|t=(V . t)| \\ I &=2 \mathrm{A} \quad(\text { given }) \\ V \cdot t &=\text { Area under } V-t \text { curve } \\ V \cdot t &=\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 600\right)+(10 \times 600) \\ &=600+6000 \\ V \cdot t &=6600 \\ E &=(6600) \times 2=13200=13.2 \mathrm{kJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 138 A two-port network shown below is excited by external dc sources. The voltages
and the currents are measured with voltmeters [latex]V_1, V_2[/latex] and ammeter [latex]A_1, A_2[/latex] (all
assumed to be ideal), as indicated. Under following switch conditions, the
readings obtained are: (i) [latex]S_1[/latex]-Open, [latex]S_2[/latex]-Closed    [latex]A_1[/latex]=0A, [latex]V_1[/latex]=4.5V, [latex]V_2[/latex]=1.5V, [latex]A_2[/latex]=1A (ii) [latex]S_1[/latex]-Closed, [latex]S_2[/latex]-Open    [latex]A_1[/latex]=4A, [latex]V_1[/latex]=6V, [latex]V_2[/latex]=6V, [latex]A_2[/latex]=0A The h-parameter matrix for this network is

Question 139 A two-port network shown below is excited by external dc sources. The voltages
and the currents are measured with voltmeters [latex]V_1, V_2[/latex] and ammeter [latex]A_1, A_2[/latex] (all
assumed to be ideal), as indicated. Under following switch conditions, the
readings obtained are: (i) [latex]S_1[/latex]-Open, [latex]S_2[/latex]-Closed    [latex]A_1[/latex]=0A, [latex]V_1[/latex]=4.5V, [latex]V_2[/latex]=1.5V, [latex]A_2[/latex]=1A (ii) [latex]S_1[/latex]-Closed, [latex]S_2[/latex]-Open    [latex]A_1[/latex]=4A, [latex]V_1[/latex]=6V, [latex]V_2[/latex]=6V, [latex]A_2[/latex]=0A The z-parameter matrix for this network is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{When,}\quad I&=0\\ \text{then,} \quad V_{1}&=4.5 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{2} &=1.5 \mathrm{V} \\ I_{2} &=1 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{1} &=Z_{11} I_{1}+Z_{12} I_{2} \\ V_{2} &=Z_{21} I_{1}+Z_{22} I_{2} \\ Z_{12} &=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0}=\frac{4.5}{1}=4.5 \\ Z_{22} &=\left.\frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0}=\frac{1.5}{1}=1.5\\ \text{When,} \quad I_{2}&=0 \\ \text{then,} \quad I_{1}&=4 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{1} &=6 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{2} &=6 \mathrm{V} \\ Z_{11} &=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\right|_{I_{2}=0}=\frac{6}{4}=1.5\\ Z_{21}&=\left.\frac{V_{2}}{I_{1}}\right|_{I_{2}=0}=\frac{6}{4}=1.5 \\ \text { So. Z-parameter matrix is }&\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1.5 & 4.5 \\ 1.5 & 1.5 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question:
Question 140 The following series RLC circuit with zero initial conditions is excited by a unit
impulse function [latex]\delta (t).[/latex] For [latex]t \gt 0[/latex], the voltage across the resistor is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} V_{R}(s)=\frac{1}{\left(s+1+\frac{1}{s}\right)} \cdot 1=\frac{s}{s^{2}+s+1} \\ =\frac{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}} \frac{1 / 2 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}} \\ V_{R}(t)=e^{-t / 2} \cos \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} t\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} e^{-t / 2} \sin \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} t\right) \\ V_{A}(t)=e^{-t / 2}\left[\cos \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} t\right)-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \sin \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} t\right)\right] \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 141 The following series RLC circuit with zero initial conditions is excited by a unit
impulse function [latex]\delta (t).[/latex] For [latex]t \gt 0[/latex], the output voltage [latex]V_{c}(t)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{C}(s)&=\frac{1}{\left(s+1+\frac{1}{s}\right)} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{s}\right)\\ &=\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1} \\ &=\frac{1}{\left(s+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}} \\ V_{C}(t) &=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} e^{-\frac{t}{2}} \sin \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} t\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 142 The circuit shown in the figure is used to charge the capacitor C alternately
from two current sources as indicated. The switches [latex]S_{1}[/latex] and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] are mechanically coupled and connected as follows: For 2nT[latex]\leq[/latex]t[latex]\leq[/latex](2n+1)T,  (n=0,1,2,..) [latex]S_{1}[/latex] to [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] to [latex]P_{2}[/latex] For (2n+1)T[latex]\leq[/latex]t[latex]\leq[/latex](2n+2)T, (n=0,1,2,...) [latex]S_{1}[/latex] to [latex]Q_{1}[/latex] and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] to [latex]Q_{2}[/latex] Assume that the capacitor has zero initial charge. Given that u(t) is a unit step function, the voltage  [latex]V_{c}(t)[/latex] across the capacitor is given be
solution: The waveform of voltage [latex]V_{c}[/latex](t) is shown below. In mathematical form, [latex] \begin{aligned} 0 \lt t \lt T, \\ C&=1 \mathrm{F}, I=1 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{c}&=\int_{0}^{t} d t=t\\ at t=T ; \quad V_{c}&=T \\ T \lt t \lt 2 T \\ V_{c}&=T-\int_{T}^{t} d t=2 T-t \\ \text { at } t=2 T ; \quad V_{C}&=0 \\ 2 T \lt t \lt 3 T \\ V_{C}&=\int_{2 T}^{t} d t=t-2 T\\ at t=3 T ; \quad V_{C}&=T \\ 3 T \lt t \lt 4 T \\ V_{C}=& T-\int_{3 T}^{t} d t=4 T-t \\ \therefore \quad V_{c}(t)=& t u(t)-2(t-T) u(t-2 T) \\ &+2(t-2 T) u(t-2 T) \ldots \\ =t u(t)+& 2 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}(t-n T) u(t-n T) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 The driving point impedance of the following network is given by [latex]Z(s)=\frac{0.2s}{s^{2}+0.1s+2}[/latex] The component values are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z(s) &=\frac{0.2 s}{s^{2}+0.1 s+2} \\ r(s) &=\frac{s^{2}+0.1 s+2}{0.2 s} \\ &=\frac{s}{0.2}+\frac{1}{2}+\frac{2}{0.2 s} \\ &=5 s+0.5+\frac{10}{s}\\ \text{Comparing with}\\ n(s) &=C s+\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{L s} \\ C &=5 F, R=\frac{1}{0.5}=2 \Omega \\ L &=\frac{1}{10}=0.1 \mathrm{H} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 144 The Thevenin equivalent impedance [latex]Z_{th}[/latex] between the nodes P and Q in the following circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{T h} &=(s+1) \|\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right) \\ &=\frac{(s+1)\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)}{(s+1)+1+\frac{1}{s}} \\ &=\frac{(s+1)^{2} / s}{(s+1)(s+1) / s}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 In the two port network shown in the figure below, [latex]Z_{12} \; and \; Z_{21}[/latex] and respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1} &=Z_{11} I_{1}+Z_{12} I_{2} \\ V_{2} &=Z_{21} I_{1}+Z_{22} I_{2} \\ Z_{12} &=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}\right|_{1_{1}=0} \\ Z_{12}&=\left.\frac{V_{2}}{I_{1}}\right|_{I_{2}=0} \\ \text { When }\quad I_{1} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{1} &=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{1}}{I_{2}}&=0=Z_{12} \\ \text{When} \quad I_{2}&=0,V_{2}=-\beta I_{1}r_{o}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{2}}{I_{1}}&=-\beta r_{0}=Z_{21} \end{aligned} \\[/latex]

question: Question 158 A two-port network is represented by ABCD parameters given by [latex]\begin{bmatrix} V_{1}\\ I_{1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} A & B\\ C&D \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} V_{2}\\ -I_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] If port-2 is terminated by [latex]R_{L}[/latex], the input impedance seen at port-1 is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1}=&A V_{2}-B I_{2} \\ I_{1}=&C V_{2}-D I_{2}\\ V_{2}=&-I_{2} R_{L} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}=& \frac{A V_{2}-B I_{2}}{C V_{2}-D I_{2}} \\ =& \frac{-A \cdot I_{2} R_{L}-B I_{2}}{-C \cdot I_{2} R_{L}-D I_{2}} \\ \text { Input impedance } =&\frac{B+A R_{L}}{D+C R_{L}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 160 The h parameters of the circuit shown in the figure are
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} V_{1}=h_{11} I_{1}+h_{12} V_{2} \\ I_{2}=h_{21} I_{1}+h_{22} V_{2} \\ h_{11}=\frac{V_{1}}{\left.I_{1}\right|_{V_{2}=0}}, \quad h_{12}=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0} \\ h_{21}=\frac{I_{2}}{\left.I_{1}\right|_{V_{2}=0}}, \quad h_{22}=\left.\frac{I_{2}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0} \\ \text { When } V_{2}=0 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{1} &=-I_{2} \\ \frac{I_{2}}{I_{1}}&=-1=h_{21} \\ V_{1} &=10 I_{1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}} &=10 \\ \text { when }\quad I_{1} &=0 \\ V_{1} &=V_{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}&=h_{12}=1\\ \text{(As no drop in 10} &\Omega \text{ resistance)}\\ V_{2} &=20I_{2}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{I_{2}}{V_{2}}&=h_{22}=\frac{1}{20}=0.05\\ \quad\left[\begin{array}{cc} 10 & 1 \\ -1 & 0.05 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 164 For the circuit shown in the figure, the instantaneous current [latex]i_{1}[/latex](t) is
