question: Question 166 The maximum power that can be transferred to the load resistor [latex]R_{L}[/latex] from the voltage source in the figure is
solution: For maximum power transfer [latex]\begin{aligned} R_{L}&= R_{s}=100 \Omega \\ \therefore \quad P_{\max }&=\frac{V^{2}}{R}=\frac{5 \times 5}{100}=0.25 \mathrm{W} \\ &\qquad\left(V \operatorname{across} R_{L}=5 \mathrm{V}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 167 In a series RLC circuit, R=2k[latex]\Omega[/latex], L=1H, and [latex]C=\frac{1}{400}\mu F[/latex] The resonant frequency is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{0} &=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{1 \times \frac{1}{400} \times 10^{-6}}} \\ &=\frac{10^{3} \times 20}{2 \pi}=\frac{10^{4}}{\pi} \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 168 The ABCD parameters of an ideal n:1 transformer shown in the figure are [latex]\begin{bmatrix} n & 0\\ 0&x \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The value of x will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{l} V_{1} \\ I_{1} \end{array}\right] &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} A & B \\ C & D \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} V_{2} \\ -I_{2} \end{array}\right] \\ -\frac{I_{2}}{I_{1}} &=\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}=\frac{n}{1} \\ V_{1} &=A V_{2}-B I_{2}\\ I_{1}&=C V_{2}-D I_{2} \\ A&=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{2}=0}=n \\ D&=-\left.\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}\right|_{V_{2}=0}=\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}=\frac{1}{n} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 169 The condition on R, L and C such that the step response y(t) in the figure has
no oscillations, is
solution: Transfer function [latex] \begin{aligned} =& \frac{\frac{1}{s C}}{R+s L+\frac{1}{s C}}=\frac{1}{s^{2} L C+s C R+1} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=& \frac{\frac{1}{L C}}{s^{2}+\frac{R}{L} s+\frac{1}{L C}} \\ 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=\frac{R}{L} \\ \omega_{n} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L C}} \\ \xi &=\frac{R}{2 L} \sqrt{L C}=\frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} \end{aligned}[/latex] For no oscillations, [latex]\xi \geq 1 [/latex] [latex] \frac{R}{2} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} \geq 1 \quad ; \quad R \geq 2 \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}[/latex]

question: Question 170 Consider the following statements S1 and S2 S1 : At the resonant frequency the impedance of a series RLC circuit is zero. S2 : In a parallel GLC circuit, increasing the conductance G results in increase in its Q factor. Which one of the following is correct?
solution: [latex]S_{1}[/latex]: Impedance of series RLC circuit at resonant frequency is minimum [latex] Z=R+j\left(\omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}\right) [/latex] [latex] \omega L-\frac{1}{\omega C}=0 [/latex] [latex] Z=R \text{(Purely resistive)} [/latex] [latex] S_{2}: Q=R \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} [/latex] [latex] G=\frac{1}{R} \Rightarrow Q=\frac{1}{G} \sqrt{\frac{C}{L}} [/latex] [latex] G \uparrow [/latex] then [latex]Q \downarrow[/latex] if [latex]C \& L[/latex] are same

options.A: S1 is FALSE and S2 is TRUE
options.B: Both S1 and S2 are TRUE
options.C: S1 is TRUE and S2 is FALSE
options.D: Both S1 and S2 are FALSE

question: Question 171 For the circuit shown in the figure, the initial conditions are zero. Its transfer function [latex]H(s)\frac{V_{c}(s)}{V_{i}(s)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s) &=\frac{\frac{1}{s C}}{R+s L+\frac{1}{s C}}=\frac{1}{s^{2} L C+s C R+1} \\ &=\frac{1}{s^{2}\left(10 \times 10^{-3} \times 100 \times 10^{-6}\right)} \\ &+s\left(10 \times 10^{3} \times 100 \times 10^{-6}\right)+1 \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{10^{-6} s^{2}+s+1}=\frac{10^{6}}{s^{2}+10^{6} s+10^{6}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 172 The transfer function [latex]H(s)=\frac{V_{o}(s)}{V_{i}(s)}[/latex] of an RLC circuit is given by [latex]H(s)=\frac{10^{6}}{s^{2}+20s+10^{6}}[/latex]. The Quality factor (Q-factor) of this circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Characteristic equation }=s^{2}+20 s+10^{6} \\ Q=\frac{\omega_{0}}{B W}, \omega_{0}=\sqrt{10^{6}} \\ Q=\frac{10^{3}}{20}=\frac{1000}{20}=50 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 173 The circuit shown in the figure has initial current [latex]i_{L}(0^{-}) = 1 A[/latex] through the
inductor and an initial voltage [latex]V_{C}(0^{-})=- 1 V[/latex]  across the capacitor. For input
v(t)=u(t), the Laplace transform of the current i(t) for t [latex]\geq[/latex]
 0 is
solution: [latex]\mathrm{KVL}, \quad v(t)=R i(t)+\frac{L d i(t)}{d t}+\frac{1}{C} \int_{0}^{\infty} i(t) d t [/latex] Taking Laplace transform on both sides, [latex] V(s)=R I(s)+L s I(s)-L I\left(0^{+}\right)+\frac{I(s)}{s C}+\frac{V_{c}\left(0^{+}\right)}{s}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{1}{s}=I(s)+s I(s)-1+\frac{I(s)}{s}-\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex] \frac{2}{s}+1=\frac{I(s)}{s}\left[s^{2}+s+1\right] [/latex] [latex] I(s)=\frac{s+2}{s^{2}+s+1}[/latex]

question: Question 174 For the lattice shown in the figure, [latex]Z_{a}=j2\Omega \; and \; Z_{b}=2\Omega[/latex]. The values of the open circuit impedance parameters [latex][Z]=\begin{bmatrix} Z_{11} &Z_{12} \\ Z_{21} & Z_{22} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] are
solution: For Lattice network, Z-parameter is given as [latex] \begin{array}{l} {\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{Z_{a}+Z_{b}}{2} \frac{Z_{a}-Z_{b}}{2} \\ \frac{Z_{a}-Z_{b}}{2} \frac{Z_{a}+Z_{b}}{2} \end{array}\right]} \\ Z_{a}=2 j, Z_{b}=2 \Omega \\ {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1+j & -1+j \\ -1+j & 1+j \end{array}\right]} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 175 For the R - L circuit shown in the figure, the input voltage [latex]v_{i}[/latex] (t) = u(t).  The current i(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I(s)&=\frac{V(s)}{s+2}=\frac{1}{s(s+2)} \\ I(s)&=\frac{1}{s(s+2)}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+2}\right] \\ i(t)&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-e^{-2 t}\right) \\ \text { At } \quad t&=0, i(t)=0 \\ t&=\infty, i(t)=0.5 \\ t&=\frac{1}{2}, i(t)=0.31 \end{aligned}[/latex] Graph (c) satisfies all conditions .

question: Question 176 For the circuit shown in the figure, the time constant RC = 1 ms. The input voltage is [latex]v_{i}(t)=\sqrt{2}sin10^{3}t[/latex]. The output voltage[latex]v_{o}(t)[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{0}(t)&=\frac{\frac{1}{j \omega C}}{R+\frac{1}{j \omega C}}\; v_{i}(t)=\frac{1}{1+j \omega C R} \sqrt{2} \sin 10^{3} t \\ &=\frac{1}{1+j \times 10^{3} \times 10^{-3}} \sqrt{2} \sin 10^{3} t \\ v_{0}(t) &=\sin \left(10^{3} t-45^{\circ}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 177 The circuit shown in the figure, with [latex]R=\frac{1}{3}\Omega ,L=\frac{1}{4}H[/latex] and C = 3 F has input voltage v(t) = sin2t. The resulting current i(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i(t)=& V(t), Y \\ Y=& V(t)\left[\frac{1}{R_{1}}+\frac{1}{j \omega L}+j \omega C\right] \\ =& \sin 2 t\left[3+\frac{4}{2 j}+j \times 2 \times 3\right] \\ =& \sin 2 t[3-2 j+6 j]=\sin 2 t[3+4 j] \\ =& 5 \sin 2 t \angle \tan ^{-1} \frac{4}{3}=5 \sin \left(2 t+53.1^{\circ}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 The equivalent inductance measured between the terminals 1 and 2 for the circuit shown in the figure is
solution: If current enters the dotte terminals of coil 1 then a voltage is developed across coil 2 whose higher potential is at dotted terminals. [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{-M d I}{d t}+\frac{L_{1} d I}{d t}-\frac{M d I}{d t}+L_{2} \frac{d I}{d t} \\ &=\left(L_{1}+L_{2}-2 M\right) \frac{d I}{d t}\\  V&=L_{e q} \frac{d I}{d t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 An ideal sawtooth voltages waveform of frequency of 500 Hz and amplitude 3 V is generated by charging a capacitor of 2 [latex]\mu F[/latex] in every cycle. The charging requires
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} v_{c}(t) &=\frac{1}{C} \int_{0}^{T} i d t \\ \text{Here } T &=\frac{1}{f}=\frac{1}{500}=2 \mathrm{msec}\\ C&=2 \mu F \\ \Rightarrow \quad 3 &=\frac{i}{2 \mu F} T \\ i &=\frac{3 \times 2 \mu F}{T}=\frac{3 \times 2 \mu F}{2 m \sec }=3 m A \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: Constant voltage source of 3 V for 1 ms
options.B: Constant voltage source of 3 V for 2 ms
options.C: Constant voltage source of 1 mA for 1 ms

question:
Question 182 The driving point impedance Z(s) of a network has the pole-zero locations as
shown in the figure. If Z(0) = 3, then Z(s) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} Z(s)=\frac{K(s-z)}{\left(s-p_{1}\right)\left(s-p_{2}\right)}=\frac{K(s+3)}{(s+1+j)(s+1-j)} \\ Z(s)=\frac{K(s+3)}{(s+1)^{2}-j 2}=\frac{K(s+3)}{(s+1)^{2}+1} \\ Z(0)|_{\omega=0}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3 K}{2}=3 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K=2 \\ \therefore \quad Z(s)=\frac{2(s+3)}{s^{2}+2 s+2} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 183 An input voltage [latex]v(t)=10\sqrt{5}\cos (t+10^{\circ})+10\sqrt{5}\cos (2t+10^{\circ})V[/latex] is applied to a series combination of resistance R = 1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and an inductance L = 1 H. The resulting steady-state current i(t) in ampere is

question: Question 184 Assume that the switch S is in position 1 for a long time and thrown to position 2 at t = 0. [latex]I_{1}(s)[/latex] and [latex]I_{2}(s)[/latex] are the Laplace transforms of [latex]i_{1}(s)[/latex] and [latex]i_{2}(s)[/latex] respectively. The equations for the loop currents [latex]I_{1}(s)[/latex] and [latex]I_{2}(s)[/latex] for the circuit shown in the figure,after the switch is brought from position 1 to position 2 at t = 0, are
solution: When switch is in position 2, KVL in loop (1), [latex] I_{1}(s) \cdot R+\frac{V}{s}+I_{1}(s) \cdot \frac{1}{s C}+\left[I_{1}(s)-I_{2}(s)\right] s L=0[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow I_{1}(s)\left[R+\frac{1}{s C}+s L\right]-I_{2}(s) \cdot s L=\frac{-V}{s} \\ \text { KVL in } \operatorname{loop}(2) \\ {\left[I_{2}(s)-I_{1}(s)\right] s L+I_{2}(s) R+I_{2}(s) \cdot \frac{1}{s C}=0} \\ \Rightarrow-I_{1}(s) \cdot s L+I_{2}(s)\left[R+S L+\frac{1}{S C}\right]=0 \\ {\left[\begin{array}{cc} R+s L+\frac{1}{s C} & -s L \\ -s L & R+s L+\frac{1}{s C} \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} I_{1}(s) \\ I_{2}(s) \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} -\frac{v}{s} \\ 0 \end{array}\right]} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 189 A series RLC circuit has a resonance frequency of 1 kHz and a quality factor Q=100. If each of R, L and C is doubled from its original value, the new Q of the circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q=& \frac{f_{o}}{B W} \\ f_{0} &=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}} \\ B W &=\frac{R}{L} \\ \text { (Characteristic equation } &\left.=s^{2}+\frac{R s}{L}+\frac{1}{L C}\right)\\ \text{or}\qquad&=\frac{1}{R} \sqrt{\frac{L}{C}} \\ \text{When R, L, C are doubled,}\\ Q&=\frac{1}{2} Q=50 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 192 If the 3-phase balanced source in figure  delivers 1500 W at a leading power
factor of 0.844, then the value of [latex]Z_{L}[/latex]  (in ohm) is approximately
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 3 V_{p} I_{\rho} \cos \theta&=1500 \\ 3\left(\frac{V_{L}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)\left(\frac{V_{L}}{\sqrt{3} Z_{L}}\right) \cos \theta&=1500 \\ Z_{L}=\frac{V_{L}^{2} \cdot \cos \theta}{1500}&=\frac{400^{2} \times 0.844}{1500}=90 \Omega\\ \theta&=\cos ^{-1}(0.844)=32.44\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] As power factor is leading, load is capacitive so angle will be negative.
